title: Will Moon Jae-in win South Korea's upcoming presidential election?
preds:
South Korea election: Polls open to choose new president BBC (2017) May 9, states that: South Koreans are voting in a presidential election, called early after a huge corruption scandal brought down their former leader. Liberal Moon Jae-in is the clear front-runner with centrist Ahn Cheol-soo his nearest challenger. The election is being closely watched at a time of economic uncertainty and heightened tensions with North Korea. Mr Moon wants to increase contact with the North in contrast to ex-leader Park Geun-hye who cut almost all ties. Observers are expecting a high turnout at the ballot boxes, with numbers boosted by younger voters, as South Koreans choose from 13 candidates. Polls close at 20:00 local time (11:00 GMT), with the winner expected to be announced soon after (para. 1-6). BBC News Website. (2017). South Korea election: Polls open to choose new president. BBC. Retrieved from
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-39848999

South Koreans are not as parochial as most westerners and have a historical trend of electing the popular candidate and not deviating from pre-poll numbers. Moon has a history and narrative that also makes Koreans feel good about their politicians, by comparison to their recent corruption issues. Jae-in also has very strong numbers by comparison to his challengers.
Based on analysis by Korean colleagues in Seoul and the US, as well as numerous news reports citing Moon's massive lead in the polls, I feel confident in his victory.
Moon leads in all public opinion polls, there is worry about outside interference in the election, however.
Based on popular opinion (which is right most of the time but can also be completely wrong).

Polls Quiet, Predata Signals Take the Pulse of the South Korean Electorate
http://beyondparallel.csis.org/polls-quiet-predata-signals-take-the-pulse-of-the-south-korean-electorate/ Taking note of the puns in the headings "Moon also rises",  "Ain't no Sunshine"... But seriously, Sunshine policy rhetoric, exceeding optimism on an economy heading for turbulence, and  at the same time allegations of Chinese meddling in the election, perhaps even hacking?
https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=de&sl=auto&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.newstown.co.kr%2Fnews%2FarticleView.html%3Fidxno%3D284947&sandbox=1

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-southkorea-election-moon-foreignpolic-idUSKBN1810PV
Looks like this lad will win.  Given my recent record, he probably won't.  It is possible to be discouraged by this.
First try and looks pretty interesting given the emergence of political risks globally

Moon is well ahead of any other candidate. I accept that polls are averages with margins of error but the size of the polling miss would be unprecedented for him to lose at this point. And yeah there is Brexit and trump but polling in the UK is notoriously bad and even there the miss was less than 4 points and regarding trump the national polls were correct in predicting a 2-4 win for Hillary (she won by just over 2 points) who only went on to lose because we still pick winners using a ridiculous system more akin to a tribal federation than a modern democracy. Point is polling just isn't wrong by enough for Moon to lose.
Moon Jae-in, the Democratic Party candidate and clear front-runner to become South Korea's next president in a snap election to be held on May 9.
More certain than this one than about the UCONN women's basketball team!
Shift in polling and tactical voting has caused me to lower my forecast
Jea-in lost last election, but is now in a strong place.

Moon Jae leads in the polls by a decisive margin. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Korean_presidential_election,_2017 South Korea presidential front runner widens lead
http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/south-korea-presidential-front-runner-widens-lead South Korea Election: Odds of Moon Victory Raised To 80%, Stocks Rally to Record High
http://www.barrons.com/articles/south-korea-election-odds-of-moon-victory-raised-to-80-1493687566 The Wisdom of the Crowds also agrees. Betting odds also favour him. The result is in. The crying in Washington has only started.
He is polling very well. Head and shoulders above the other contenders.

Polling figures from multiple sources give moon a 20pt margin (large sample sizes)- 92%
The aggression of North Korean rhetoric in spite of American missile system plans, public perception of new approach needed - 95%
Recognisable figure opposed to corrupt conservative party - 96%

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Korean_presidential_election,_2017#2017_May Recent opinion polls gave Moon Jae-in between 37.7 and 41.8%, far higher than the next contender, Ahn Cheol-soo, whose best predicted vote share was 23.9%. Also, https://www.predictit.org/Market/3064/Who-will-win-the-South-Korean-presidential-election currently gives Moon Jae-in a 96% chance.
